item.title: By: Anonymous in Teaneck
item.dc:creator: Anonymous in Teaneck
item.description: I can understand why, in a past where fewer people were literate and/or wrote about their actions, sermons could possibly be "the most important genre for social history." But in today's world of blogs, listservs, self-published books, surveys, Facebook, and Youtube, this claim would be difficult to support. You don't need to "mine sermons for religious behavior and deviance," which are, after all, not primary sources. The primary sources are out there.
